Efficient CuZn/SiO2 lamellar catalysts for methanol dehydrogenation: New insights into the role of zinc Yanhong Quan Conceptualization Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft a b Yuting Jin Data curation Methodology Writing – review & editing a b Na Wang Conceptualization Methodology a b Jinxian Zhao Writing – review & editing a b Jun Ren Supervision Project administration Writing – review & editing a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China b Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology (Taiyuan University of Technology), Ministry of Education, China Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology (Taiyuan University of Technology), Ministry of Education China Key Laboratory of Coal Science and Technology (Taiyuan University of Technology), Ministry of Education ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China. State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China CuZn/SiO2 lamellar catalysts are obtained through the introduction of zinc oxide with different amount to Cu/SiO2 prepared by the ammonia-evaporation method and investigated for the dehydrogenation of methanol to methyl formate. The 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst showed the best catalytic activity with a methanol conversion of 44.5% and a selectivity to methyl formate of ~92.7% at 300 °C and 0.2 MPa. The reason for this excellent activity could be ascribed to the strong interaction between Cu and ZnO, which promoted the decomposition of the copper phyllosilicate precursor to release copper oxide and thereby achieved more active Cu0 species upon reduction on the catalyst surface. In addition, the agglomeration of Cu species was mainly responsible for the slight decline in the methanol conversion in ZnO modified Cu based catalysts for the methanol dehydrogenation reaction. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methanol Methyl formate (MF) Copper phyllosilicate xCuZn/SiO2 Zinc oxide 1 Introduction Methyl formate (MF) with aldehyde and ester groups can be widely used to synthesize numerous high value-added products, including more than 50 chemicals, such as formic acid, ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate [1]. In addition, MF is also used in the pharmaceutical, pesticide, leather, dye and rubber industries. The synthesis routes of MF mainly include the esterification of methanol and formic acid [2], liquid-phase methanol carbonylation [3], methanol dehydrogenation [4], oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol [5,6], the one-step syngas method [7] and carbon dioxide hydrogenation condensation with methanol [8]. From a global perspective, there is an urgent need for the cleaner production of chemical products because it is crucial for the implementation of sustainable development goals [9]. Therefore, the dehydrogenation of methanol to MF has attracted increasing attention as a result of its abundant raw materials and pollution-free products, which make this reaction a green conversion. As described in Eqs. (1) and (2), in the methanol dehydrogenation reaction, MF is produced as the main product, with the formation of carbon monoxide (CO) and H2 as the main by-products, as shown in Eq. (3) [10]: (1) CH3OH → CH2O + H2 (2) CH2O + CH3OH → HCOOCH3+ H2 (3) HCOOCH3→2CO+ H2 Noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pd and Pt) [11] and transition metals (Cu and Ni)[12] are active for the dehydrogenation of methanol. As shown in Eqs. (1)–(3), methanol dehydrogenation to MF involves in the cleavage of both OH and CH bonds, which is closely related to the adsorption configuration of the reaction intermediates of formaldehyde on the active sites [13]. Sun et al. [14] confirmed that formaldehyde is the primary product of methanol dehydrogenation by in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. Moreover, Iwasa [11] illustrated a distinction between Cu and other metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Pt and Ni), where the adsorption configuration of Cu with only the O atom of formaldehyde bonded to the metal surface contributes to its desorption, whereas the configuration with the linkage of both C and O atoms on the surface of Pt or other metals favors its decomposition to CO and H2. In addition, compared with noble metals, Cu-based catalysts are widely used for the methanol dehydrogenation reaction in both industry and academia due to their low price and high methanol conversion [14,15]. It has been reported that the activity of Cu-based catalysts is greatly determined by the nature of the support. Cu catalysts supported on different carriers (e.g., SiO2 [16], ZnO [17], ZrO2 [18], Cr2O3 [19], MgO [10] and carbon [20]) have been extensively studied. Among these, Cu/SiO2 catalysts have shown the best catalytic performance in the dehydrogenation of methanol due to the weak alkaline properties of SiO2. Conversely, the supports with acid sites induce the dehydration of methanol to produce dimethyl ether, thereby deteriorating the MF selectivity [21]. For Cu/SiO2 catalysts, despite the question of the required Cu species remaining controversial, metallic Cu species are usually considered to be responsible for superior catalytic performance in MF formation [15,20,22]. Furthermore, it is conducive to the cleavage of the OH bond in methanol and the CH bond in the reaction intermediates of CH3O and H2COOCH3 formed from CH3O and HCHO [23]. Nevertheless, metallic copper nanoparticles are prone to aggregation and sintering due to their low Hütting temperature (~178 °C) and Tammann temperature (~405 °C), which consequently cause inactivation of the catalysts under operating temperatures higher than 300 °C, representing one of the major issues for Cu-based catalysts in thermodynamically unfavorable reactions [24,25]. The agglomeration of Cu/SiO2 catalysts is a prevalent and critical problem in various reactions, as recognized by many researchers [26]. To solve this problem, one of the most significant and effective approaches is to design several unique structures, including core-shell [27], core-sheath [28], nanotube [29], lamellar [30] and ordered mesoporous materials [31]. For instance, Yang et al. [27] prepared a core-shell structured Cu@SiO2 catalyst with excellent performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, which was attributed to the confined effect of the silica shell. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the lamellar structure was preferred due to the strong metal-oxide and metal-support interactions [28]. Recently, metal phyllosilicates, including those based on Ni [32], Co [33], Cu [29] and Fe [34], have received increasing attention for the dry reforming of methane, the selective hydrogenation of esters, the water-gas shift reaction and dimethyl ether steam or ethanol reforming. This is because they can be converted to silica supported metal (or metal oxide) catalysts with unique layered structure incorporated ions after reduction, composed of octahedral (metal coordinated to oxygen atoms or hydroxyl groups) and tetrahedral SiO4 sheets [35]. Fan et al. reported that nickel phyllosilicate with entrapped Ni nanoparticles showed excellent activity for the selective hydrogenation of guaiacol to 2-methoxycyclohexanol [36] and glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-propanediol [37]. Liu [38] prepared a Ni phyllosilicate catalyst for CO2 methanation and achieved high anti-sintering properties and stability due to its strong metal-support interaction and good Ni dispersion. Similarly, Kawi et al. [39] used copper phyllosilicate as a water-gas shift catalyst and found that the phyllosilicate structure promoted the dispersion of small nanoparticles, which showed good activity and excellent resistance of coking. Significantly, it has been confirmed by numerous studies that metal phyllosilicate precursors provide the resulting catalysts with highly dispersed metallic nanoparticles with an outstanding confinement effect, thereby further promoting the performance. By contrast, ZnO is known to be a promising promoter for improving the activity of Cu catalysts in the dehydrogenation of methanol and is also deemed as an effective strategy for inhibiting Cu aggregation [12,40]. Zhao et al. [12] found that the activity of the hydrogenation of methyl acetate depended on the Cu/Zn ratio due to the interaction between the Cu and ZnO species, which inhibited the sintering of the Cu nanoparticles. ZnO additives can enhance the adsorption capacity [40] and provide more active sites [41,42] for the methanol decomposition reaction due to the presence of a high abundance of defect sites and lattice distortion on the Zn surface. Koitaya et al. [43] concluded that there exists a synergetic effect between the ZnO islands and the partially oxidized Cu substrate for the dehydrogenation of methanol. In our previous work, the promotion of ZnO for Cu/SBA-15 in the methanol dehydrogenation reaction was also confirmed [14]. Various methods, including deposition-precipitation (DP) [44,45], hydrothermal [46], selective adsorption of copper tetraammine [47] and ammonia evaporation hydrothermal (AEH) [37,48,49], have been developed for MF synthesis and have a significant effect on the structure and catalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts. For example, Cheng et al. [25] found that more 2:1 copper phyllosilicate formed when prepared from a simple co-precipitation method and more 1:1 copper phyllosilicate was detected in a Cu/SiO2 catalyst derived from urea hydrolysis DP. It was worth noting that 1:1 copper phyllosilicate with the Si/Cu ratio of about 1 was often known as chrysocolla [Cu2Si2O5(OH)2], while 2:1 copper phyllosilicate with the Si/Cu ratio of about 2 was also called Cu-talc. Nevertheless, copper phyllosilicates species existed in all catalysts, which further resulted in inferior catalytic performance in ester hydrogenation to ethanol over a Cu co-precipitation catalyst than a Cu-DP catalyst, mainly due to the small amount of active copper species on the surface after reduction. Recently, the AEH method has drawn more attention for the easy formation of copper phyllosilicate (Cu2SiO5(OH)2) with a lamellar structure and consequently resulted in excellent performance in many catalytic reactions. A Cu/SiO2 catalyst derived from a copper phyllosilicate precursor prepared with the AEH method exhibited superior catalytic performance compared with that from an impregnation method in the glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-propanediol [37] and water-gas shift reactions [39]. Xu et al. [50] explored the influence of the temperature of the AEH method on the texture, composition and structure of Cu/SiO2 catalysts and catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to ethylene glycol. Louis [47] investigated the influence of several preparation parameters on the relative amount of the two supported CuII species, including grafted CuII ions and copper phyllosilicate, which revealed the formation mechanism of copper phyllosilicate. From the above studies, it can be inferred that the AEH method shows significant advantages in contributing to the formation of copper phyllosilicate with the lamellar structure, which promoted the exposure of more terminal –OH groups anchoring the active metal on the surface of silica, as well as possessing open two-dimensional channels that transfer heat and mass [11,15]. This provides a favorable strategy to improve the anti-agglomeration performance of silica-supported Cu catalysts. In this study, Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 lamellar catalysts are synthesized by the AEH method and their catalytic performance is examined by the gas-phase dehydrogenation of methanol to MF. The loading of ZnO is modulated and the influence of ZnO content on the support structure and Cu sites is investigated. Furthermore, special emphasis is given to the evolution of both copper phyllosilicate and copper active sites caused by the ZnO additives. The key factor in influencing the catalytic activity and stability is also revealed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2.6H2O), copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2.3H2O) and ammonia aqueous solution (NH3·H2O) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Silica sol was purchased from Qingdao Ocean Chemical Co., Ltd. (Qingdao, China) and used without further treatment. High-purity N2 (> 99.99%), Ar (> 99.99%) and H2 (> 99.99%) were provided by the Jining Xieli Special Gases Co., Ltd. (Shandong, China). 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The Cu/SiO2 catalysts with a Cu loading of 20 wt% were prepared by the AEH method as follows [47]. Cu(NO3)2.3 H2O (4.86 g) was dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water and 9.2 mL of the 28 wt% ammonia aqueous solution were slowly added until the copper ammonia complex was generated under vigorous stirring for 30 min. Then, 8 g of silica gel were added into the copper ammonia complex solution under stirring for an additional 4 h at room temperature. Consequently, the above solution was transferred to a water bath preheated at 80 °C to allow for the evaporation of ammonia and the decrease of pH from 11/12–6/7, followed by filtration and washing three to four times with deionized water. The resulting filter cake was dried for 12 h at 120 °C and then calcinated for 4 h at 450 °C in muffle oven, followed by reducing with a 30% H2/N2 flow for 4 h at 400 °C in a tube furnace. The ZnO-modified Cu/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by a wet impregnation approach. Specifically, the dry Cu/SiO2 precursors were immersed in a Zn(NO3)2 solution and then oscillated in an ultrasonic cleaner for 30 min. The obtained mixture was then transferred into a rotary evaporator and conducted at 80 °C to remove the water. The calcined catalyst was consequently achieved from drying for 12 h at 120 °C, followed by calcination for 4 h at 450 °C. The reduction method was then used and was the same as that for the Cu/SiO2 catalysts described above. The final sample was then denoted as xCuZn/SiO2 (x = 10, 20 or 30), in which x represented the mol ratio of Cu to Zn. 2.3 Characterization techniques The morphology of the samples was measured by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL, JEM-2100 F, Tokyo, Japan). Before the measurements, the samples were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol and supported on a copper or molybdenum grid. The analysis of the crystal structure and phase composition of the catalysts was carried out by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Rigaku D/max 2500 diffraction with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The voltage and current of the measurements were operated at 40 kV and 100 mA, respectively, with a scanning rate of 8°/min in the 2θ range of 5–80°. The FTIR spectra of the samples were recorded on a Thermo fisher Nicolet iS5 spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. 1 mg powder samples were finely dispersed in 100 mg KBr and then pressed into a thin wafer for tests. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were determined at −196 °C on a micromeritics 3 H-2000PS2 instrument (BeiShiDe). Prior to the measurement, 120–150 mg samples were pretreated with He gas at for 3 h 200 °C. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface areas were calculated from the adsorption branch at P/P0 = 0.04–0.32. The total pore volume was estimated from the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at P/P0 = 0.99. The surface Cu species of the reduced catalysts were detected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (XAES) using a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with an Al-Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). The binding energies were calibrated by the binding energy of C 1 s at 284.5 eV. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a Finsore-3010 apparatus (Zhejiang FINETEC). For H2-TPR, 50 mg of samples were pretreated in an Ar flow for 60 min at 200 °C before reduction in 5% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) from room temperature to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. A thermal conductivity detector was used to record the hydrogen consumption during the reduction. The copper dispersion and metallic copper surface area were measured by N2O titration on a XianQuan TP-5080 instrument. The sample was reduced at 400 °C in a 10 vol% H2/Ar gas mixture (30 mL/min) and cooled to 50 °C with Ar (30 mL/min). Subsequently, the reduced sample was exposed to 10 vol% N2O/Ar (30 mL/min) for 30 min, ensuring that all the surface Cu atoms were completely oxidized. The H2-TPR experiment was then carried out in a 10% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) gas mixture at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The CH3OH temperature-programmed desorption (CH3OH-TPD) was carried out on a XianQuan TP-5080 instrument. The sample was first degassed at 200 °C under a helium flow (30 mL/min) for 1 h. After degassing, the temperature of the sample was maintained at 100 °C. CH3OH steam was then introduced to the sample cell (using He as a carrier gas) to allow the sample to adsorb CH3OH until saturation, followed by flushing with He to remove all physically adsorbed molecules. The temperature of the sample was raised until 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The methanol released from the sample was continuously monitored by with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The Cu and Zn contents in the catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical omission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on a Thermo iCAP6300 device. 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic properties of the Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts for the dehydrogenation of methanol were studied in a fixed-bed reactor under 0.2 MPa at 300 °C [14]. First, 0.3 g of catalyst were diluted with 3 g of quartz sand between plugs of quartz wool and preheated in a H2 flow at 400 °C for 4 h with N2 used as an equilibrium gas. Methanol was then injected at 3 mL h−1 through a Series Ⅲ pump, which was vaporized in the preheater and then fed into the reactor for catalytic dehydrogenation using N2 as a carrier gas (30 mL/min). After condensation in the condenser, the effluents (including methanol, MF, H2, CO2 and CO) were collected and then analyzed offline through a gas chromatograph (GC-920, Shanghai Haixin) with a TDX-01 column (500 mm × 8 mm) using thermal conductivity and with a PEG-20 M Polar capillary column using flame ionization detectors, respectively. The methanol conversion (CMeOH, %), MF selectivity (SMF, %), CO2 selectivity ( S CO 2 , %), CO selectivity (SCO, %) and MF yield (YMF, %) were calculated according to the following equations, respectively: (2) C MeOH = 2 ×n MF +n CO 2 +n CO n MeOH + 2 ×n MF +n CO 2 +n CO × 100 % (3) S MF = 2 ×n MF 2 ×n MF +n CO 2 + n CO × 100 % (4) S CO 2 = n CO 2 2 ×n MF +n CO 2 + n CO × 100 % (5) S CO = n CO 2 ×n MF +n CO 2 + n CO × 100 % (6) Y MF = C MeOH × S MF × 100 % In the above equations, nMeOH, nMF, nCO and nCO2 was the molar ratio of methanol, MF, CO and CO2 in exhaust gas, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 Physicochemical properties The physicochemical properties of the Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Table 1. The Cu and Zn concentrations of the reduced catalysts were determined by ICP-OES. As shown in Table 1, the actual copper metal loadings are lower than the design value due to the loss of metallic ions in the washing process, whereas the values for ZnO are close to the theoretical values, which is consistent with the results in the literature [41]. The textural properties of the calcined and reduced Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts were investigated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isothermal measurements and are displayed in Fig. S1. All the catalysts exhibit the same type-IV isotherm and an obvious H1 hysteresis loop in the P/P0 range of 0.4–1.0, indicating the existence of a mesoporous structure. This result suggests that the mesoporous structure is maintained in all samples, although the catalysts are modified by the addition of ZnO and even reduced by the hydrogen atmosphere. However, the distinction in the relative P/P0 rang of 0.4–0.6 of nitrogen adsorption isotherms between the reduced and the calcined catalysts were observed and the hysteresis loops of the reduced catalysts was smaller than the calcined ones, further confirming destroy of copper phyllosilicates structure upon reduction. Additionally, there were two peaks with pore size centered at 3.5 and 5.5 nm in the pore size distribution curves for both reduced and calcined catalysts, which were showed in Fig. 1. Nevertheless, the relative proportion of the first peak area to the second peak area in the reduced catalysts decreases obviously compared with the calcined catalyst accordingly. This result demonstrated that the pores with the size of pores of copper phyllosilicate, would be destroyed once the catalyst is reduced. Noticeably, numerous pores of ~3.5 nm still remain, suggesting the presence of a portion of copper phyllosilicate in the reduced catalysts [51]. The specific surface area and detailed pore parameters of the calcined catalysts are summarized in Table 1. Noticeably, the evident change is observed for the structure of catalysts with increasing ZnO loading and their surface areas decrease gradually as the molar ratio between Cu and Zn decreases from 30 to 10. The 10CuZn/SiO2 catalyst exhibits the smallest surface area of 379 m2/g, with a significant reduction compared with that of Cu/SiO2 (432 m2/g). The reason appears to be related to the collapse of porous copper phyllosilicate with the high specific surface area caused by the excessive amount of ZnO introduced [37]. 3.1.2 Crystalline phase and morphology The XRD patterns in Fig. 2 show the structures of the calcined and reduced Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts. Obviously, the weak and broad diffraction peak at 2θ of 22.5° could be assigned to the feature peak of amorphous SiO2 in all the calcined and reduced samples. Fig. 2(A) illustrated that the calcined samples displayed the weak peaks 2θ located at 30.8° and 35.0° except 10CuZn/SiO2, which were assigned to the copper phyllosilicate phase [Cu2SiO5(OH)2] (JCPDS card 27-0188) [47,51]. For all the calcined catalysts, the diffraction peaks centered at 2θ of 35.6°, 38.8°, 48.7°, 58.4°, 61.8° and 66.2° belonging to CuO phase were observed, which was consistent with the report that a part of copper phyllosilicate would start to decompose at 450 °C to form CuO [47]. The diffracting peaks for CuO increased with the addition of ZnO, indicating that ZnO promoted the decomposition of copper phyllosilicate and led to the formation of bulk CuO crystallites. Moreover, only the 10CuZn/SiO2 catalyst presents the very weak diffraction peaks at 2θ of 31.8°, 34.4°, 36.3°, 56.7°, 62.9° and 67.9° corresponding to ZnO phase (JCPDS card 75-1526), indicative of the formation of ZnO crystallites on the catalyst surface. In contrast, no diffraction peak belonging to ZnO is observed in the 20CuZn/SiO2 and 30CuZn/SiO2, revealing a high dispersion of ZnO on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 2(B), all reduced catalysts show distinct diffraction peaks centered at 2θ of 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.2°, attributed to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of metallic Cu (JCPDS card 04–0836), respectively. The peak at 2θ of 36.4° corresponding to the Cu2O (111) plane (JCPDS card 05–0667) is observed in the four catalysts. Compared with XRD patterns of the calcined samples, the characteristic peaks assigning to the copper phyllosilicate phase and CuO species disappeared, while the characteristic peaks attributed to Cu2O and metallic Cu were observed clearly in the reduced samples, suggesting that CuO was reduced to metallic Cu species while copper phyllosilicate was reduced to Cu2O due to the presence of a strong interaction between the copper species and silica support. Similar behavior has been reported where only CuO was reduced to metallic Cu species and this was ascribed to the presence of copper phyllosilicate and the partial transformation of copper phyllosilicate to CuO in Cu/SiO2 catalysts after calcination [20,24]. In addition, significant difference exists in the intensity of the diffraction peaks of metallic Cu for the reduced Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts seen from Fig. 2(B). The diffraction peaks of metallic Cu first become weak and then strengthen along with ZnO additive loading. The 30CuZn/SiO2 catalyst possesses the weakest peak of metallic Cu, while 10CuZn/SiO2 shows the strongest one, indicating that the introduction of excessive ZnO is capable of leading to an increase in large copper particles, consistent with that of the copper dispersion obtained from the N2O titration tests [12]. The observation was probably attributed to that the presence of strong interaction between the ZnO and Cu in xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts with appropriate amount of ZnO, which promoted the decomposition of copper phyllosilicate to produce CuO in the calcination procedure and further caused the formation of metallic copper through reduction process [51]. For achieving detailed information of the reduced 10CuZn/SiO2, the XRD patterns of Fig. 2(B) in the range of 30–40° are amplified and shown in Fig. 2(C). It is notable that the peak at 36.4° is asymmetric in the 10CuZn/SiO2 catalyst and obviously different from the other three catalysts, which could be due to the overlaying of the two peaks assigned to Cu2O and ZnO (at ~36.1°) (JCPDS card 75–1526). Beyond this, the other two obvious peaks at 31.8° and 34.4° can be discriminated from the XRD patterns of the reduced 10CuZn/SiO2 catalyst, which further confirms the presence of ZnO species [51,52]. However, no diffraction peaks for ZnO are observed in the reduced 20CuZn/SiO2 and 30CuZn/SiO2 catalysts, which is likely due to the high dispersion and homogeneous distribution of the ZnO species generated at the relatively low loading. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of the reduced Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts. Large amounts of thin nanotubes can be clearly observed from Fig. S2(a) and (b), suggesting the formation of copper phyllosilicates in calcined catalysts prepared by the AEH method [35,48]. As shown in Fig. 3, all the reduced catalysts clearly demonstrate that the typical filandrous morphology of copper phyllosilicate is destroyed to varying degrees upon reduction, whereas dark spherical particles attributable to Cu species emerged. It is noticeable that the particles become larger with the introduction of ZnO, indicating the important effect of ZnO additives on the size and dispersion of Cu particles on the surface of the reduced catalysts. More importantly, the reduced 20CuZn/SiO2 possesses less of a filandrous structure compared with the reduced Cu/SiO2. This phenomenon suggests that both the reduction of catalysts and the introduction of ZnO are responsible for the decomposition of copper phyllosilicates and thus the crystallinity of the lamella decreases [25]. Furthermore, only in the reduced 10CuZn/SiO2 catalyst does the 0.269 nm lattice fringe assigned to the ZnO (002) lattice plane emerge, in agreement with the XRD results [53,54]. It is deemed that an appropriate amount of ZnO can contribute to its high dispersion on the surface of xCuZn/SiO2 and further promote the dispersion of Cu species, while an excessive amount of ZnO covers the active Cu species, which was further confirmed by the elemental mappings of reduced 10CuZn/SiO2 in Fig. S3. Fig. 4 displays the FTIR spectra of the calcined catalysts with different ZnO amounts and reduced 20CuZn/SiO2. The adsorption band at 1630 cm−1 is assigned to the bending mode of the OH groups of the absorbed water. The adsorption band of the asymmetric stretching vibrations of the SiOSi bond in SiO2 is at 1100 cm−1, while the band for the symmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si is at 800 cm−1 [29]. The formation of copper phyllosilicates is supported by the existence of the adsorption band at 670 cm−1, assigned to the δOH bands and the shoulder peak at frequency vibrational band of 1040 cm−1 [25,48]. Compared with pure SiO2 and reduced 20 CuZn/SiO2, all the calcined catalysts presented the characteristic peaks of copper phyllosilicates. Furthermore, the relative amount of copper phyllosilicates in the calcined catalysts can be estimated by considering the integrated intensity of the δOH bands at 670 cm−1 normalized to that at 800 cm−1, which is termed as I670/I800 [55,56]. It is noted that the I670/I800 ratio only gives a qualitative estimation of the amount of copper phyllosilicate in that the extinction coefficients of the corresponding FTIR bands are not known. Fig. 4(B) clearly illustrates that the relative amount of copper phyllosilicates presents a downward trend as the ZnO content increases, indicating that the addition of ZnO is able to cause damage to the structure of the copper phyllosilicates. Noticeably, the trend becomes more moderate as the ZnO amount continues to increase compared with the 20CuZn/SiO2 with 30CuZn/SiO2 catalysts, which can be explained by the presence of the stable T-O-T (2:1) copper phyllosilicates structure. As reported in the literature, two types of layered structure of both T-O (1:1) and T-O-T (2:1) copper phyllosilicates coexist in the as-prepared catalysts, of which 1:1 copper phyllosilicates are unstable and tend to decompose at high temperature [25,36]. However, the more reasonable explanation should be that the Cu species in T-O-T (2:1) copper phyllosilicates are too far apart to form a strong interaction between ZnO and Cu, thereby inhibiting the decomposition of the copper species. In addition, compared with the calcined 20CuZn/SiO2 catalysts, the disappearance of the δOH band at 670 cm−1 and the blue shift of νSiO shoulder peak from 1040 to 1049 cm−1 occurred in the FTIR spectra of reduced catalyst, indicating the destroy of the lamellar structure during the process of hydrogen reduction, which consistent with the results of previous studies. [25,51]. 3.1.3 Interaction between Cu and ZnO species Fig. 5 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the calcined xCuZn/SiO2 and Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The width of the reduction temperature peak of xCuZn/SiO2 gradually increases with increasing ZnO loading, with a nearly identical onset of 170 °C but varied terminating temperature shifts from 320° to 450°C, indicative of the variation in the amount of different copper species for the calcined samples. The Cu/SiO2 and 30CuZn/SiO2 catalysts display a reduction peak centered at around 170–340 °C, attributed to the collective contribution of the reduction of the well-dispersed CuO to Cu0 and the Cu-O-Si of the copper phyllosilicate to Cu+, since a further reduction of Cu+ to Cu0 requires a high temperature of > 600 °C [56]. Compared with Cu/SiO2, 30CuZn/SiO2 possessed less amount of copper phyllosilicate as verified by the FTIR results and more well-dispersed CuO, which should be responsible for the distinction in the shape and position of the H2-TPR profiles between them. For the 20CuZn/SiO2 and 10CuZn/SiO2 catalysts, the peak higher than 340 °C is assigned to the reduction of large CuO particles to metallic Cu, in which the amount of bulk CuO particles in the former is lower than that in the latter. It is noted that the variation of the copper dispersion deduced from the H2-TPR profiles is Cu/SiO2 ≈ 30CuZn/SiO2 > 20CuZn/SiO2 > 10CuZn/SiO2, which is highly consistent with that determined by N2O titration ( Table 2). Combined with the FTIR and TEM results, it is reasonable to conclude that the two copper species of well-dispersed CuO and copper phyllosilicate are present in the calcined Cu/SiO2 and 30CuZn/SiO2 catalysts, while bulk CuO as the third copper species is also in the 20CuZn/SiO2 and 10CuZn/SiO2 catalysts. In other words, the copper species in the calcined catalysts change greatly as a result of the different degrees of damage for the copper phyllosilicate structure with the formation of the interaction between Cu and ZnO with different ZnO loadings. Fig. 6 shows the XPS analysis for the Zn 2p region of the reduced xCuZn/SiO2 catalyst. The intensive photoelectron peaks observed can be deconvoluted into two peaks, with the lower binding energy at 1021.5–1021.7 eV assigned to ZnO species [52] and the higher binding energy at 1022.4–1022.6 eV attributed to the ZnO species strongly interacting with the Cu species [51]. The presence of the strong interaction between the ZnO and Cu species causes a weakening of the CuOSi bond in the copper phyllosilicates and further promotes its decomposition. It is noteworthy that the proportions of two types of ZnO species varied distinctly in all the xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts. With increasing Zn, the portion of Zn species at higher binding energies first increases and then decreases. It is reasonable to deduce that the introduction of ZnO at an appropriate amount can promote the strong interaction between ZnO and Cu species, while an excess amount of ZnO contributes to the appearance of larger particles due to the aggregation of more CuO nanoparticles generated from the decomposition of copper phyllosilicates[51]. These results are in accordance with the XRD and H2-TPR results. 3.1.4 Surface chemical states The Cu 2p XPS and XAES spectra of the reduced xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 7(a) and 7(b), respectively. Typically, the peaks at 932.4 and 952.2 eV are assigned to the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively. According to previous reports, the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy of CuO is located at 933.5 eV, but the binding energy of highly dispersed Cu2+ interacting with silica is discovered at 934.9 eV [51,57]. Fig. 7(a) shows that in all reduced catalysts, copper existed in the oxidation state of Cu2+, as evidenced by the Cu 2p3/2 peak at 935.1 eV and the satellite peak at 943.7 eV. The occurrence of Cu2+ may be due to the inevitable partial oxidation of the sample during the test. In this work, the binding energy of Cu 2p1/2 located at 932.4 eV and Cu 2p3/2 located at 952.2 eV are assigned to Cu+ and/or Cu0. In the Cu LMM XAES spectra of the reduced catalysts (Fig. 7(b)), the asymmetry and broad peak is observed and deconvoluted into two symmetrical peaks centered at about 916.6 and 913.0 eV, corresponding to Cu0 and Cu+, respectively. [25] Compared with the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the auger electron peak shifted to the lower kinetic energy of 916.3 and 911.5 eV, respectively, indicating that the formation of stronger interaction between copper and ZnO in xCuZn/SiO2 than that in Si-O-Cu with the introduction of zinc additives. [2] Moreover, the relative percentages of different copper species were calculated from the corresponding peak areas in the Cu 2p and Cu LMM spectra, with the results given in Table 2. Based on these deconvolution results, the concentration of Cu0 first increases with increasing Zn species and reaches a maximum of 58.9% when the molar ratio of Cu/Zn is 20 and then drops to 51.7% with a further increment in Zn loading. This result indicates that the Cu0 concentration on the surface is heavily dependent on the Zn content. As reported by Wang et al. [51], an appropriate amount of ZnO species can promote the concentration of Cu0 species on the catalyst surface due to the strong interaction between the Cu and ZnO species. As confirmed by the FTIR results, the additional Cu0 species generated in 20CuZn/SiO2 stem from the decomposition of the copper phyllosilicate induced by the stronger Cu-ZnO interaction with the increased ZnO loading. However, when the Cu/Zn mole ratio was 10 with Zn loading increasing, some copper phyllosilicate was sacrificed to produce more CuO during the calcination procedure and yet the surface specific area decreased, which probably caused the aggregation of these CuO particles to form in bulk on the catalyst surface, as confirmed by XRD results. The formed bulk CuO particles were more difficult to be reduced than well-dispersed CuO, which eventually resulted in decrease of catalytic activity. The result might be responsible for the poorer dispersion of copper species along with the lower concentration of metallic Cu in all Cu species in the 10CuZn/SiO2 catalyst than that in 20CuZn/SiO2. 3.1.5 CH3OH-TPD General agreement is achieved between the investigations concerning methanol adsorption via hydrogen bonding and decomposition on the well-defined metal surface, where a methoxy species, CH3O, is formed during dissociative adsorption and is decomposed near 100 °C to give formaldehyde and MF [58]. Moreover, Gabriela Díaz et al [59] verified that methanol desorption peaks are observed in all samples around 110 °C using on-line mass spectrometry. In addition, the H2 and CO originated at higher temperature about 200 °C respectively, from gradually dehydrogenation of methoxy and formate intermediate species [59,60]. Overbury et al. [61] reported methanol adsorption at room temperature led to different types of methoxy species, and some MF and possibly carbonate species are retained after high-temperature desorption by in situ FIIR and Raman spectroscopy as well as mass spectrometry. In our study, degassing and the subsequent adsorption of CH3OH steam in the CH3OH-TPD test for all the samples are carried out at 100 °C. The CH3OH-TPD profiles of the Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 8. Three desorption peaks are identified in all catalysts and the desorption temperatures are in the ranges of 45–170, 170–290 and 290–400 °C, corresponding to the physically-adsorbed methanol, the oxidative products (e.g. CO2 and H2O)[23,63]; as well as stronger chemisorbed species (formaldehyde and MF) [62,63] or decomposition product (H2 and CO) [59,60], respectively. It can be seen that the peak area and position of desorption varied greatly. The area and position of desorption peaks varied greatly, which was assumed to be seriously related to the active species on the catalyst surface [41], induced by the interaction between the ZnO and Cu species. For the first peak at ~100 °C, all the catalysts exhibit a similar shape and position. Nevertheless, the second peak (~210 °C) corresponding to oxides, CO2 and H2O, is clearly distinct when the ratio of Cu to Zn decreases from 30 to 10 and the area of that in the 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst is the lowest, suggesting that the risk of further decomposition of MF is smaller than the others. 3.2 Dehydrogenation of methanol to MF 3.2.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts for the dehydrogenation of methanol to MF is shown in Table 3. The Cu/SiO2 shows a relatively low CMeOH of 37.2%, an SMF of 83.1% and a YMF of 30.9%. With increasing ZnO loading, the catalytic activity of the catalyst showed a volcano-type catalytic behavior in terms of CMeOH, SMF and YMF. Among all the catalysts, 20CuZn/SiO2 exhibits the highest activity with an excellent CMeOH of 44.5%, an SMF of 92.7% and a YMF of 41.3%, which are significantly superior to those reported in the literature. Thus, this result indicates that moderately tuning the ZnO loading on the surface of Cu/SiO2 and the interaction between Cu and ZnO species could be of importance for optimizing the catalytic performance. It is well known that Cu0 plays a dominant role in the dehydrogenation of methanol to MF. Cu0 sites enable the cleavage of the OH bond in methanol to give CH3O, followed by HCHO by breaking a CH bond, whereas Cu+ sites cause the rapid decomposition of HCHO into CO and H2 [23]. In a previous study, we also investigated the effect of Cu0 contents on the catalytic activity of Cu-based catalysts and found that the concentration of Cu0 presents a volcanic curve with increasing ZnO loading. The CMeOH and SMF also present a similar trend. A schematic diagram showing the influence of the ZnO amount on the copper phyllosilicate catalysts is presented in Fig. 9. Specifically, the presence of the interaction between Cu and ZnO upon introducing the ZnO promoter into the Cu/SiO2 catalyst weakens the CuOSi bond of copper phyllosilicates and thus causes its decomposition, as confirmed by the H2-TPR and FTIR results. The copper phyllosilicates tend to generate well dispersed CuO on the catalyst surface in the calcination process and a higher ratio of Cu0 species in the reduced xCuZn/SiO2 was achieved and detected than that in Cu/SiO2 by the XPS results. As revealed by Helveg [64], copper nanoparticles on a silica support formed during the reduction of homogeneous copper phyllosilicate platelets by H2, mainly because the plate-like structure of the precursor restricted the diffusion of copper and the autocatalytic reduction limited the probability for secondary nucleation. Furthermore, the influence of the incorporated Zn amount on the catalyst structure should be sufficiently considered. An excessive amount of ZnO causes the collapse of most copper phyllosilicates and further induces a decrease in the specific surface area, which may be responsible for the formation of the large particles and the sharp decline in Cu dispersion from 17.0% to 7.9%, as identified by TEM and N2O titration. Considering the presence of ZnO was also verified by the XRD and TEM results of 10CuZn/SiO2, another plausible explanation was that the Cu species in the 2:1 copper phyllosilicates were too far apart to interact with the introduced ZnO and thus large ZnO particles formed, accompanied with a small amount of CuO released from the residual 1:1 copper phyllosilicates aggregated due to the decreasing specific surface area. which resulted in a decrease of Cu0 concentration from 58.9% in 20CuZn/SiO2 to 51.7% in 10CuZn/SiO2. Therefore, copper phyllosilicates were decomposed with the ZnO loading through the enhanced interaction between ZnO and Cu, which is ultimately conducive to tuning the concentration of Cu0 and the amount of the stable type of lamellar structure. In other words, more Cu0 species were formed at the expense of copper phyllosilicates. Moreover, the ZnO amount is important to the adsorption of CH3OH on active Cu species, as revealed by the CH3OH-TPD results, where the 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst displays a larger area for the third peak compared to the other catalysts. This indicates that an appropriate amount of ZnO is beneficial to the formation of MF or other carbon oxides [65]. Notably, the highest Cu0 concentration is observed in the 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst, which displays the best catalytic performance. 3.2.2 Stability of catalysts Fig. 10 shows the stability test at 300 °C used to estimate the stability of the Cu/SiO2 and 20CuZn/SiO2 catalysts. The 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst shows satisfactory catalytic performance and is stable up to 60 h, especially for the selectivity to MF, maintaining 94% of initial performance over the course. Conversely, the activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst drops sharply within only 20 h and declined by ~26% under identical reaction conditions. Therefore, it may be inferred that the addition of ZnO can help to improve the performance and stability of the catalyst. The reason for the inactivation of the 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst is discussed below. Firstly, no obvious variation in the content of Cu0 species is detected after the stability test (Table S1), as proved by the Cu 2p XPS and Cu LMM XAES spectra of the used catalysts (Fig. S4), indicating that Cu0 can be maintained after the dehydrogenation reaction and the catalysts are not oxidized during the catalyst test [46]. However, it was seen from the Fig. S5 that the spent 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst presented the hysteresis loop of type H1 in the P/P0 range of 0.7–1.0, significantly smaller than the reduced one, implying that the most of mesoporous structure was reserved and yet the amount of mesoporous of catalyst showed an obvious decrease during the reaction process. This was consistent with pore size distribution curves. Moreover, the visible change of textural properties was observed in 20CuZn/SiO2 and Cu/SiO2 during reaction and particularly the surface areas decrease from the reduced catalyst of 305 and 210 m2/g to the spent one of 68 and 43 m2/g, respectively (Table S1). Furthermore, the pore distribution of 3 nm belonging to the interlayer pores of copper phyllosilicate entirely disappears in the spent catalyst, indicating that the lamellar structure collapses. Furthermore, TEM and XRD confirmed that the particle size on the catalyst surface obviously grows (Figs. S3 and S4), which means the occurrence of agglomeration for Cu species during the reaction. The main peaks at 20.7º and 26.4º belonging to SiO2 are observed due to the quartz wool plugging the catalyst. Notably, a greater increase for the average size of the particles is observed in Cu/SiO2 than that in the 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst after long-term testing, indicating that 20CuZn/SiO2 is relatively resistant to agglomeration due to the introduction of ZnO species. According to the literature, the deactivation and low stability of Cu-based nanoparticles is predominantly ascribed to the loss of active species caused by sintering [26] and carbon deposition [51] and Combined with the above results, it is speculated that the decline in the catalytic performance of the 20CuZn/SiO2 and Cu/SiO2 catalysts results from the agglomeration of Cu species during the reaction, which is ascribed to the decreased specific area due to the collapse of the lamellar structure. More importantly, the appropriate addition of ZnO is favorable in suppressing the agglomeration of copper crystallites in Cu-based catalysts effectively, thereby consequently extending their lifetimes [25]. 4 Conclusion A series of Cu/SiO2 and xCuZn/SiO2 (x = 10, 20 or 30) catalysts were prepared by the AEH method for the dehydrogenation of methanol to MF. It was found that the xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts exhibited superior activity than Cu/SiO2 and the ZnO amount has a dramatic effect on the catalytic activity and stability in methanol dehydrogenation. The introduction of ZnO can promote the decomposition of copper phyllosilicates by enhancing the interaction between ZnO and Cu, which is ultimately conducive to adjusting the concentration of Cu0 and the amount of the stable type of copper phyllosilicate. In all cases, 20CuZn/SiO2 showed the best catalytic performance with an excellent CMeOH of 44.5%, SMF of 92.7% and YMF of 41.3% at 300 °C, which could be predominantly associated with the highest Cu0 concentration. In addition, the results demonstrated that a higher Cu0 ratio can be achieved by sacrificing copper phyllosilicate by adjusting the ZnO amount in the xCuZn/SiO2 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: CuZn/SiO2 lamellar catalysts are obtained through the introduction of zinc oxide with different amount to Cu/SiO2 prepared by the ammonia-evaporation method and investigated for the dehydrogenation of methanol to methyl formate. The 20CuZn/SiO2 catalyst showed the best catalytic activity with a methanol conversion of 44.5% and a selectivity to methyl formate of ~92.7% at 300 °C and 0.2 MPa. The reason for this excellent activity could be ascribed to the strong interaction between Cu and ZnO, which promoted the decomposition of the copper phyllosilicate precursor to release copper oxide and thereby achieved more active Cu0 species upon reduction on the catalyst surface. In addition, the agglomeration of Cu species was mainly responsible for the slight decline in the methanol conversion in ZnO modified Cu based catalysts for the methanol dehydrogenation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient CuZn/SiO2 lamellar catalysts for methanol dehydrogenation: New insights into the role of zinc
